etymologies: Old English sǣd, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zaad, German Saat, also to the verb sow

definitions: a flowering plant's unit of reproduction, capable of developing into another such plant

examples.text: cut open the peppers and remove the seeds

shortDefinitions: unit of reproduction of flowering plant

examples.text: you can grow artichokes from seed

definitions: the cause or latent beginning of a feeling, process, or condition

examples.text: the conversation sowed a tiny seed of doubt in his mind

shortDefinitions: cause or latent beginning of feeling or condition

definitions: (chiefly in biblical use) a person's offspring or descendants

examples.text: as he promised to our forefathers, Abraham and his seed

definitions: any of a number of stronger competitors in a sports tournament who have been assigned a specified position in an ordered list with the aim of ensuring that they do not play each other in the early rounds

examples.text: he knocked the top seed out of the championships

shortDefinitions: several stronger competitors in sports tournament who have been assigned specified position in ordered list

definitions: a small crystal introduced into a liquid to act as a nucleus for crystallization.
shortDefinitions: small crystal introduced into liquid to act as nucleus for crystallization

definitions: a small container for radioactive material placed in body tissue during radiotherapy.
shortDefinitions: small container for radioactive material placed in body tissue during radiotherapy

examples.text: the shoreline is seeded with a special grass

definitions: sow (a particular kind of seed) on or in the ground

examples.text: after seeding forage into the duff, they now have grassland mixed with mature forest

definitions: cause (something) to begin to develop or grow

examples.text: severance payouts that help seed their new businesses

shortDefinitions: cause something to begin to develop or grow

definitions: place a crystal or crystalline substance in (something) in order to cause crystallization or condensation (especially in a cloud to produce rain)

examples.text: potential hail clouds are observed by radar, then seeded by lead iodide fired into the cloud's center

shortDefinitions: place crystal or crystalline substance in

definitions: (of a plant) produce or drop seeds

examples.text: mulches encourage many plants to seed freely

definitions: (of a plant) reproduce itself by means of its own seeds
shortDefinitions: (of plant) reproduce itself by means of its own seeds

definitions: remove the seeds from (vegetables or fruit)
give (a competitor) the status of seed in a tournament

examples.text: Jeff Tarango, seeded five, was defeated by fellow American Todd Witsken

shortDefinitions: give competitor status of seed in tournament
